case_name: Man Mohan Chawla v. J.S. Sethi

facts.text: Man Mohan Chawla was tenant since before 1958 in premises in Delhi belonging to J.S. Sethi.

anchor.surface_text: Man Mohan Chawla was since before l958 tenant in certain premises in Delhi belonging to J.S. Sethi.

facts.text: Contractual rent of the premises was Rs. 160 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractual rent of the premises was Rs. 160 per month. Sethi filed petition under s. 14 1  of the Delhi

facts.text: Sethi filed petition under s. 14(1) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 for ejectment against Chawla on ground of default in paying rent for seven months consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: Sethi filed petition under s. 14 1  of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 for an order in ejectment against Chawla on the plea that the latter had companymitted default in paying rent for seven months companysecutively.

facts.text: Chawla deposited the rent claimed pursuant to direction of Rent Controller, amount paid to Sethi, first proceeding disposed of.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to a direction of the Rent Controller, Chawla deposited the rent claimed, and the amount deposited was paid over to Sethi and the proceeding was disposed of.

facts.text: Chawla committed default in payment of rent for three consecutive months after first proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: Chawla again companymitted default for three companysecutive months, and Sethi companymenced another proceeding under s. 14 1  of the Delhi Rent Control Act for an order in ejectment.

facts.text: Sethi commenced second proceeding under s.14(1) for ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: Chawla again companymitted default for three companysecutive months, and Sethi companymenced another proceeding under s. 14 1  of the Delhi Rent Control Act for an order in ejectment.

facts.text: Chawla pleaded he sent Rs. 320 by postal money order to Sethi on March 19, 1963 which Sethi refused.

anchor.surface_text: Chawla denied the claim that he had companymitted default in payment of rent. He pleaded that he had on March 19, 1963 sent to Sethi Rs. 320 by a postal money order which Sethi had refused to accept.

facts.text: Sethi denied that postal money order was brought to him by postal peon.

anchor.surface_text: Sethi denied that a money order sent by Chawla was brought to him by the postal peon.

facts.text: Chawla pleaded contractual rent excessive, standard rent could not exceed Rs. 50 per month, prayed for fixation of standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: Chawla also pleaded that the companytractual rent was excessive and that the rent of the premises let to him companyld number exceed Rs. 50 per month and prayed that standard rent may be fixed by the Controller.

facts.text: Rent Controller rejected Chawla's contentions and passed order of ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller rejected that companytention of Chawla and passed an order in ejectment.

facts.text: Order of ejectment confirmed in appeal by Rent Control Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of ejectment passed by the Controller was companyfirmed in appeal by the Rent Control Tribunal,

facts.text: Second appeal to Delhi High Court unsuccessful, judgment dated January 24, 1969 in S.A.O. No. 203-D of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1461 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 24, 1969 of the Delhi High Court in S.A.O. No. 203-D of 1966.

facts.text: Chawla appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: C. Misra and R.P. Aggarwal, .for the appellant. Hardev Singh and S.K. Gambhir, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: All courts held Chawla failed to prove postal money order was sent to Sethi and refused.

anchor.surface_text: All the Courts have held that Chawla had failed to prove his case that a postal money order for Rs. 320 sent by Chawla was duly addressed to Sethi and that Sethi refused to accept the postal money order when it was tendered to him.

facts.text: Only evidence was postal receipt for Rs.320 to Sethi, did not bear residential address.

anchor.surface_text: The only evidence in support of that case was a postal receipt for despatch of a money order for Rs. 320 to Sethi. It did number bear the residential address of Sethi.

facts.text: Sethi deposed no one tendered postal money order to him, testimony believed.

anchor.surface_text: Sethi deposed that numberone had tendered to him the postal money order. His testimony has been believed.

facts.text: Chawla obtained benefit under s.14(2) in first proceeding by depositing rent.

anchor.surface_text: By depositing the amount in companyrt in the previous proceeding, Chawla clearly obtained the benefit under s. 14 2  in respect of the premises occupied by him as a tenant.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1461 of 1969 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1461 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 24, 1969

facts.text: Counsel for Chawla: C. Misra and R.P. Aggarwal.

anchor.surface_text: C. Misra and R.P. Aggarwal, .for the appellant. Hardev Singh and S.K. Gambhir, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Man Mohan Chawla was since before l958 tenant in certain premises

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contractual rent governs until Controller fixes standard rent under s.9; ss.4,5 apply post-determination.

holdings.text: Under the scheme of the Act, standard rent is that amount only which the Controller determines; until fixed by Controller, contractual rent determines tenant's liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents evasion of s.12 limitation; otherwise limitation nugatory; consistent with Act's scheme.

holdings.text: The expression 'shall' in s.15(1) is directory; tenant entitled to hearing to show payment before deposit order.

anchor.surface_text: Even though the expression shall is used, it is, in our judgment, directory. The tenant is entitled to show that he has paid the rent claimed from him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory order without hearing would preclude tenant defence and encourage false claims.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interim rent at last paid rate till standard rent fixed separately under s.9/12; 'having regard to provisions of Act' refers to ss.9,12.

holdings.text: Chawla obtained benefit under s.14(2) in first proceeding by depositing rent, barring second benefit under proviso.

anchor.surface_text: By depositing the amount in court in the previous proceeding, Chawla clearly obtained the benefit under s. 14 2 in respect of the premises occupied by him as a tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First proceeding disposed after deposit; proviso to s.14(2) expressly bars repeat benefit after prior default and benefit.

holdings.text: Rent Controller, Tribunal, and High Court were right in rejecting Chawla's plea for standard rent fixation in ejectment proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the Rent Controller, the Rent Control Tribunal and the High Court were right in the view they have expressed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea barred by s.12 limitation; no jurisdiction under s.15(3) for standard rent determination.

holdings.text: Chawla failed to prove postal money order was duly addressed and tendered to Sethi, who refused it.

holdings.text: High Court judgments allowing standard rent fixation in ejectment misconstrue 1958 Act compared to 1952 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The judgments to which our attention was invited appear to have proceeded upon earlier judgments... difference in phraseology of 1958 Act not noticed

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1958 Act lacks express provision for determination in suit/proceeding unlike 1952 Act ss.8-11.

precedents.citation: Jiwan Industries Private Ltd. v. Santosh Company 1

anchor.surface_text: In Jiwan Industries Private Ltd. v. Santosh Company 1 .--Bedi, J., held that the Rent Controller companyld fix the standard rent in a proceeding in ejectment even after the application of the landlord for ejectment of the tenant had been dismissed. In Messrs Suraj Balram Sawhney Sons. v. Dr. D. Kiri 2 --Gurdev Singh, J., held that the Controller had jurisdiction under s. 15 3  to determine the standard rent in an application for ejectment based on the plea of numberpayment of rent, if the tenant raised a companytention that the companytractual rent is in excess of the standard rent.

precedents.case_name: Jiwan Industries Private Ltd v Santosh Company
precedents.cited_proposition: Rent Controller could fix standard rent in ejectment proceeding even after dismissal of landlord's ejectment application
precedents.cited_holding: the Rent Controller companyld fix the standard rent in a proceeding in ejectment even after the application of the landlord for ejectment of the tenant had been dismissed

precedents.citation: Messrs Suraj Balram Sawhney Sons. v. Dr. D. Kiri 2

anchor.surface_text: In Messrs Suraj Balram Sawhney Sons. v. Dr. D. Kiri 2 --Gurdev Singh, J., held that the Controller had jurisdiction under s. 15 3  to determine the standard rent in an application for ejectment based on the plea of numberpayment of rent, if the tenant raised a companytention that the companytractual rent is in excess of the standard rent. The learned Judge was of the view that the language of sub-s.  3  of s. 15 companyers even those cases in which an application for fixation of standard rent it made independently would be barred by time prescribed under s. 12 of the Act

precedents.case_name: Messrs Suraj Balram Sawhney Sons v Dr D Kiri
precedents.cited_proposition: Controller has jurisdiction under s.15(3) to determine standard rent in ejectment proceedings where tenant claims contractual rent exceeds standard rent, even if time-barred under s.12
precedents.cited_holding: the Controller had jurisdiction under s. 15 3  to determine the standard rent in an application for ejectment based on the plea of numberpayment of rent, if the tenant raised a companytention that the companytractual rent is in excess of the standard rent

precedents.citation: S.K. Chatterjee and Anr. v.J.N. Ghoshal 3

anchor.surface_text: In S.K. Chatterjee and Anr. v.J.N. Ghoshal 3  S.K. Kapur J., held that the words any dispute as to the amount of rent payable by the tenant in sub-s.  3  of s. 15 refers to the dispute arising between the parties on account of claim of a party for fixation of standard rent. The learned Judge further held that s. 15  3   in terms companyfers powers to order payment or deposit of arrears at the interim rate of rent.

precedents.case_name: SK Chatterjee and Anr v JN Ghoshal
precedents.cited_proposition: Dispute as to amount of rent in s.15(3) includes claim for fixation of standard rent; s.15(3) confers power to fix interim rent overriding agreed rent
precedents.cited_holding: the words any dispute as to the amount of rent payable by the tenant in sub-s.  3  of s. 15 refers to the dispute arising between the parties on account of claim of a party for fixation of standard rent

precedents.citation: Chander Bhan v. Nand Lal and Anr.  1

anchor.surface_text: S. Deshpande, J., in Chander Bhan v. Nand Lal and Anr.  1 ---observed that his observation in the case which is under appeal in this case that the expression having regard to the provisions of this Act used in s. 15  3   seemed to refer inter alia to ss. 9 and 12 of the Act, and that observation was number strictly necessary for the decision of that case inasmuch as there was numberdispute as to the rate of rent in that case and hence s. 15 3  was number attracted at all.

precedents.case_name: Chander Bhan v Nand Lal and Anr
precedents.cited_proposition: Two distinct provisions for fixing standard rent: s.9 (with limitation under s.12) and s.15(3) for disputes in ejectment; 'having regard to provisions of Act' refers to ss.9,12
precedents.cited_holding: there were two distinct provisions in the Act for fixation of standard rent--the first in s. 9 under which an application for the fixation of standard rent is made, for which limitation is provided by s. 12 of the Act the other is in s. 15 3  of the Act, and that applies only when there is a genuine dispute between the parties regarding the rate and the amount of rent

precedents.citation: Lala Manohar Lal Nathan Mal v. Madan Lal Murari Lal 2

anchor.surface_text: The judgments to which our attention was invited appear to have proceeded upon earlier judgments of the Punjab High Court in Lala Manohar Lal Nathan Mal v. Madan Lal Murari Lal 2   1 1969 All India Rent Control Journal 623. A. I. R. 1956 Pb. 190. and Smt. Radhey Piari v.S. Kalyan Singh 1 . But both these cases were decided on the interpretation of ss. 8 to 11 of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 38 of 1952

precedents.case_name: Lala Manohar Lal Nathan Mal v Madan Lal Murari Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: Standard rent could be fixed in ejectment proceedings under 1952 Act

precedents.citation: Smt. Radhey Piari v.S. Kalyan Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: and Smt. Radhey Piari v.S. Kalyan Singh 1 . But both these cases were decided on the interpretation of ss. 8 to 11 of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 38 of 1952 in which it was expressly provided that the standard rent shall be fixed on an application made to the Court for that purpose or in an application in any suit or in any proceeding. We need express numberopinion whether the cases under the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 38 of 1952 were companyrectly decided.

precedents.case_name: Smt Radhey Piari v S Kalyan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Standard rent could be fixed in ejectment proceedings under 1952 Act
